Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
TITLE: Integrating acoustics, behavior, and radio telemetry to develop a novel technique of measuring acoustic amplitude in unrestricted, free-living animals

Acoustic communication plays an integral role in mediating the behavioral interactions of many species. Research aimed at connecting variation in acoustic signals to their intended functions and effects on fitness has focused almost exclusively on differences in signal structure while largely ignoring the role of variation in amplitude (loudness). Measuring amplitude is challenging because amplitude varies depending on the distance between the signaler and the microphone and the orientation of the signaler in relation to the microphone. Consequently, current knowledge of the functional significance and fitness implications of amplitude modulation is based solely on non-quantitative observations or measures of absolute amplitude collected from animals restricted to a specific location or arena in the lab or field. Research supported by this proposal will develop a novel technique for measuring amplitude in free-living animals using microphone-transmitters, a type of radio-transmitter that enables a microphone to remain a relatively fixed distance from a mobile, vocalizing animal.

The fellow will be trained in the physics of sound production and propagation while developing skills for assaying the directionality of acoustic signals, computer programming, and calculating mathematical correction factors to account for changes in acoustic frequency (pitch) and the posture of the signaler. This research will contribute to the training and mentorship of diverse undergraduates in both laboratory and field techniques in biology and physics. In addition, the research will foster a new inter-departmental collaboration between UC Davis and UT Austin. All results will be disseminated broadly through public lectures to local Audubon Societies, publications in scholarly journals, and presentations at national and international conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Across the animal kingdom, acoustic communication plays an essential role in mediating social interactions that can affect access to resources, mating success, and survival. Previous research aimed at connecting variation in acoustic signals to their intended functions and effects on fitness has focused almost exclusively on differences in signal structure, such as frequency (pitch) and timing (rate), while largely ignoring the role of amplitude (loudness). Animals are known to vary their acoustic amplitude both in different types of social interactions and in response to changes in background noise. However, accurately measuring amplitude is challenging due to the fact that amplitude varies depending on the distance between the sound source and the microphone and the orientation of the sound source in relation to the microphone. As a consequence, our current understanding of the importance of changes in amplitude is based solely on casual observations of amplitude differences (e.g., soft v. loud song) or direct measures of amplitude collected from animals that are restricted to a specific location or arena. Thus, a persistent barrier to our ability to measure amplitude in unrestricted, free-living animals has been constraints associated with our recording techniques.

In this project, we sought to develop a novel technique for measuring amplitude in free-living animals through the use of microphone-transmitters (mic-transmitter), a type of radio-transmitter that enables a microphone to remain a relatively fixed distance from a mobile, vocalizing animal. First, we conducted a laboratory experiment where a recently sacrificed red-winged blackbird had its sound production organ, or syrinx, replaced with a tiny speaker that allowed us to model sound production by producing frequency sweeps with the speaker that then traveled out through the trachea and bill just like a normal bird song. These models were then placed inside a circular array of microphones and a mic-transmitter was fitted to their backs to allow us to simultaneously measure acoustic amplitude with both the traditional microphones in the array and the mic-transmitter. We found that as the frequency of sound increases, the amplitude disparity between the front and back of the bird also increases. Because the mic-transmitter must be attached to the back of the bird, these data are essential for calculating a correction algorithm to translate any amplitude measurements from the mic-transmitter on the back of the bird into an amplitude measurement from in front of the bird. To test the accuracy of our model and the associated calculations, we repeated this experiment with live red-winged blackbirds and the analysis of these data is ongoing. In addition, we also tested the effects of degradation of the mic-transmitter signal on amplitude measurement.

Broader Impacts:

Research funded by this award established a novel collaboration between the University of California, Davis, and the University of Texas at Austin. Two biology graduate students were mentored in techniques related to avian field biology and one mechanical engineering graduate student was mentored in topics related to bioacoustics and avian physiology. Outreach to the public and young scientists was accomplished by presentations at a local high school and the Discovery Museum in Sacramento, California. The results of this research have been disseminated to the scientific community through one peer-reviewed publication and multiple presentations at both the local and national level. At the time of this writing additional manuscripts and presentations are also being prepared. All recordings from live birds will be contributed to the Macaulay Library of Natural Sounds for archiving and use in future research...
